1.verse: The Word Made Flesh - In the beginning was the Word. The Word was close beside God, and the Word was God.

2.verse: In the beginning, he was close beside God.

3.verse: All things came into existence through him; not one thing that exists came into existence without him.

4.verse: Life was in him, and this life was the light of the human race.

5.verse: The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness did not overcome it.

6.verse: There was a man called John, who was sent from God.

7.verse: He came as evidence, to give evidence about the light, so that everyone might believe through him.

8.verse: He was not himself the light, but he came to give evidence about the light.

9.verse: The true light, which gives light to every human being, was coming into the world.

10.verse: He was in the world, and the world was made through him, and the world did not know him.

11.verse: He came to what was his own, and his own people did not accept him.

12.verse: But to anyone who did accept him, he gave the right to become God’s children; yes, to anyone who believed in his name.

13.verse: They were not born from blood, or from fleshly desire, or from the intention of a man, but from God.

14.verse: And the Word became flesh, and lived among us. We gazed upon his glory, glory like that of the father’s only son, full of grace and truth.

15.verse: John gave evidence about him, loud and clear. ‘This is the one’, he said, ‘that I was speaking about when I told you, “The one who comes after me ranks ahead of me, because he was before me.” ’

16.verse: Yes; it’s out of his fullness that we have all received, grace indeed on top of grace.

17.verse: The law, you see, was given through Moses; grace and truth came through Jesus the Messiah.

18.verse: Nobody has ever seen God. The only-begotten God, who is intimately close to the father – he has brought him to light.

19.verse: The Evidence of John - This is the evidence John gave, when the Judaeans sent priests and Levites from Jerusalem to ask him, ‘Who are you?’

20.verse: He was quite open about it; he didn’t try to deny it. He said, quite openly, ‘I am not the Messiah.’

21.verse: ‘What then?’ they asked. ‘Are you Elijah?’ ‘No, I’m not,’ he replied. ‘Are you the Prophet?’ ‘No.’

22.verse: ‘Well, then, who are you?’ they said. ‘We’ve got to take some kind of answer back to the people who sent us. Who do you claim to be?’

23.verse: ‘I’m “a voice calling in the desert”,’ he said, ‘ “Straighten out the road for the master!” ’ – just as the prophet Isaiah said.

24.verse: The people who had been sent were from the Pharisees.

25.verse: They continued to question him. ‘So why are you baptizing’, they asked, ‘if you aren’t the Messiah, or Elijah, or the Prophet?’

26.verse: ‘I’m baptizing with water,’ John replied. ‘But there is someone standing among you that you don’t know,

27.verse: someone who is to come after me. I’m not good enough to undo his sandal-strap.’

28.verse: This took place in Bethany beyond the Jordan, where John was baptizing.

29.verse: The Lamb and the Spirit - The next day, John saw Jesus coming towards him. ‘Look!’ he said. ‘There’s God’s lamb! He’s the one who takes away the world’s sin!

30.verse: He’s the one I was speaking about when I said, “There’s a man coming after me who ranks ahead of me, because he was before me!”

31.verse: I didn’t know who it would be, but this was the reason I came to baptize with water – so that he could be revealed to Israel.’

32.verse: So John gave this evidence: ‘I saw the spirit coming down like a dove out of heaven and remaining on him.

33.verse: I didn’t know who it would be; but the one who sent me to baptize with water said to me, “When you see the spirit coming down and resting on someone, that’s the person who will baptize with the holy spirit.”

34.verse: Well, that’s what I saw, and I’ve given you my evidence: he is the son of God.’

35.verse: The First Disciples - The following day John was again standing there, with two of his disciples.

36.verse: He saw Jesus walking by, and said, ‘Look! There goes God’s lamb!’

37.verse: The two disciples heard him say this, and they followed Jesus.

38.verse: Jesus turned and saw them following him. ‘What do you want?’ he asked. ‘Rabbi,’ they said (the word means ‘teacher’), ‘where are you staying?’

39.verse: ‘Come and see,’ he replied. So they came, and saw where he was staying, and stayed with him that day. It was late in the afternoon.

40.verse: One of the two who heard what John said and followed Jesus was Andrew, Simon Peter’s brother.

41.verse: The first person he found was his own brother Simon. ‘We’ve found the Messiah!’ he said (that means ‘the anointed one’, like our word ‘Christ’).

42.verse: He brought him to Jesus. Jesus looked at him. ‘So,’ he said, ‘you’re Simon, John’s son, are you? We’d better call you Cephas!’ (That means ‘the Rock’, like our word ‘Peter’.)

43.verse: Philip and Nathanael - The next day Jesus decided to go to Galilee, where he found Philip. ‘Follow me,’ he said to him.

44.verse: Philip came from Bethsaida, the town where Andrew and Peter hailed from.

45.verse: Philip found Nathanael. ‘We’ve found him!’ he said. ‘The one Moses wrote about in the law! And the prophets, too! We’ve found him! It’s Jesus, Joseph’s son, from Nazareth!’

46.verse: ‘Really?’ replied Nathanael. ‘Are you telling me that something good can come out of Nazareth?’ ‘Come and see,’ replied Philip.

47.verse: Jesus saw Nathanael coming towards him. ‘Here he comes,’ he said. ‘Look at him! He’s a real Israelite. Genuine through and through.’

48.verse: ‘How did you get to know me?’ asked Nathanael. ‘Oh,’ replied Jesus, ‘I saw you under the fig tree, before Philip spoke to you.’

49.verse: ‘Rabbi,’ replied Nathanael, ‘you’re the son of God! You’re the king of Israel!’

50.verse: ‘Wait a minute,’ said Jesus. ‘Are you telling me that you believe just because I told you I saw you under the fig tree? You’ll see a lot more than that!

51.verse: ‘In fact,’ he went on, ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth. You’ll see heaven opened, and God’s angels going up and down upon the son of man.’

1.verse: Water into Wine - On the third day there was a wedding at Cana in Galilee. Jesus’ mother was there,

2.verse: and Jesus and his disciples were also invited to the wedding.

3.verse: The wine ran out. Jesus’ mother came over to him. ‘They haven’t got any wine!’ she said.

4.verse: ‘Oh, Mother!’ replied Jesus. ‘What’s that got do to do with you and me? My time hasn’t come yet.’

5.verse: His mother spoke to the servants. ‘Do whatever he tells you,’ she said.

6.verse: Six stone water-jars were standing there, ready for use in the Jewish purification rites. Each held about twenty or thirty gallons.

7.verse: ‘Fill the jars with water,’ said Jesus to the servants. And they filled them, right up to the brim.

8.verse: ‘Now draw some out’, he said, ‘and take it to the chief steward.’ They did so.

9.verse: When the chief steward tasted the water that had turned into wine (he didn’t know where it had come from, but the servants who had drawn the water knew), he called the bridegroom.

10.verse: ‘What everybody normally does’, he said, ‘is to serve the good wine first, and then the worse stuff when people have had plenty to drink. But you’ve kept the good wine till now!’

11.verse: This event, in Cana of Galilee, was the first of Jesus’ signs. He displayed his glory, and his disciples believed in him.

12.verse: After this, he went down to Capernaum, with his mother, his brothers and his disciples. He remained there for a few days.

13.verse: Jesus in the Temple - It was nearly time for the Judaean Passover, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.

14.verse: In the Temple he found people selling cows, sheep and doves, and the money-changers sitting there.

15.verse: He made a whip out of cords and drove them all out of the Temple, sheep, cows and all. He spilt the money-changers’ coins onto the ground, and knocked over their tables.

16.verse: ‘Take these things away!’ he said to the people selling doves. ‘You mustn’t turn my father’s house into a market!’

17.verse: His disciples remembered that it was written, ‘The zeal of your house has eaten me up.’

18.verse: The Judaeans had this response for him. ‘What sign are you going to show us’, they said, ‘to explain why you’re doing this?’

19.verse: ‘Destroy this Temple,’ replied Jesus, ‘and I’ll raise it up in three days.’

20.verse: ‘It’s taken forty-six years to build this Temple,’ responded the Judaeans, ‘and are you going to raise it up in three days?’

21.verse: But he was speaking about the ‘temple’ of his body.

22.verse: So when he was raised from the dead, his disciples remembered that he had said this, and they believed the Bible and the word which Jesus had spoken.

23.verse: While he was in Jerusalem during the Passover festival, several people came to trust in his name, because they had seen the signs he did.

24.verse: But Jesus didn’t entrust himself to them. He knew everything,

25.verse: and had no need for anyone to give him information about people. He himself knew what was inside people.

1.verse: Jesus and Nicodemus - There was a man of the Pharisees called Nicodemus, a ruler of the Judaeans.

2.verse: He came to Jesus by night. ‘Rabbi,’ he said to him. ‘We know that you’re a teacher who’s come from God. Nobody can do these signs that you’re doing, unless God is with him.’

3.verse: ‘Let me tell you the solemn truth,’ replied Jesus. ‘Unless someone has been born from above, they won’t be able to see God’s kingdom.’

4.verse: ‘How can someone possibly be born’, asked Nicodemus, ‘when they’re old? You’re not telling me they can go back a second time into the mother’s womb and be born, are you?’

5.verse: ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ replied Jesus. ‘Unless someone is born from water and spirit, they can’t enter God’s kingdom.

6.verse: Flesh is born from flesh, but spirit is born from spirit.

7.verse: Don’t be surprised that I said to you, You must be born from above.

8.verse: The wind blows where it wants to, and you hear the sound it makes; but you don’t know where it’s coming from or where it’s going to. That’s what it’s like with someone who is born from the spirit.’

9.verse: ‘How can this be so?’ asked Nicodemus.

10.verse: ‘Well, well!’ replied Jesus. ‘You’re a teacher of Israel, and yet you don’t know about all this?

11.verse: I’m telling you the solemn truth: we’re talking about things we know about. We’re giving evidence about things we’ve seen. But you won’t admit our evidence.

12.verse: If I told you earthly things and you don’t believe, how will it be if I tell you heavenly things? Are you going to believe then?

13.verse: And nobody has gone up into heaven except the one who came down from heaven, the son of man.’

14.verse: The Snake and the Love of God - ‘So, just as Moses lifted up the snake in the desert, in the same way the son of man must be lifted up,

15.verse: so that everyone who believes in him may share in the life of God’s new age.

16.verse: This, you see, is how much God loved the world: enough to give his only, special son, so that everyone who believes in him should not be lost but should share in the life of God’s new age.

17.verse: After all, God didn’t send the son into the world to condemn the world, but so that the world could be saved by him.

18.verse: ‘Anyone who believes in him is not condemned. But anyone who doesn’t believe is condemned already, because they didn’t believe in the name of God’s only, special son.

19.verse: And this is the condemnation: that light has come into the world, and people loved darkness rather than light, because what they were doing was evil.

20.verse: For everyone who does evil hates the light; people like that don’t come to the light, in case their deeds get shown up and reproved.

21.verse: But people who do the truth come to the light, so that it can become clear that what they have done has been done in God.’

22.verse: The Bridegroom and His Friend - After this, Jesus and his disciples went into the countryside of Judaea, and he stayed there with them and baptized.

23.verse: John, too, was baptizing at Aenon, close to Salim. There was plenty of water there, and people came to him and were baptized.

24.verse: This, of course, was before John had been put into prison.

25.verse: There was, perhaps inevitably, a dispute between the disciples of John and a Judaean, on the subject of purification.

26.verse: They came to John. ‘Rabbi,’ they said. ‘Remember the man who was with you beyond the Jordan, the one you gave evidence about? Well, look! He’s baptizing, and everyone’s going to him!’

27.verse: ‘Nobody can receive anything unless heaven first gives it,’ replied John.

28.verse: ‘You yourselves can bear me out that I said I wasn’t the Messiah, but that I was sent ahead of him.

29.verse: It’s the bridegroom who gets the bride. The bridegroom’s friend, who stands nearby and hears him, is very, very happy when he hears the bridegroom’s voice. So, you see, my joy is now complete.

30.verse: He must increase, but I must decrease.’

31.verse: The one who comes from above is over everything. The one who is from the earth has an earthly character, and what he says has ‘earth’ written all over it. The one who comes from heaven is above all.

32.verse: He gives evidence about what he has heard and seen, and nobody accepts his evidence.

33.verse: The one who does accept his evidence has put his signature to the fact that God is true.

34.verse: The one God sent, you see, speaks God’s words, because he gives the spirit lavishly.

35.verse: The father loves the son and has given everything into his hand.

36.verse: Anyone who believes in the son shares in the life of God’s new age. Anyone who doesn’t believe in the son won’t see life, but God’s wrath rests on him.

1.verse: The Woman of Samaria - So when Jesus knew that the Pharisees had heard that he was making more disciples than John, and was baptizing them

2.verse: (Jesus himself didn’t baptize people; it was his disciples who were doing it),

3.verse: he left Judaea and went back to Galilee.

4.verse: He had to go through Samaria,

5.verse: and he came to a town in Samaria named Sychar. It was near the place which Jacob gave to his son Joseph.

6.verse: Jacob’s well was there. So Jesus, tired from the journey, sat down there by the well. It was about midday.

7.verse: A Samaritan woman came to draw water, and Jesus spoke to her. ‘Give me a drink,’ he said.

8.verse: (The disciples had gone off into the town to buy food.)

9.verse: ‘What!’ said the Samaritan woman. ‘You, a Jew, asking for a drink from me, a woman, and a Samaritan at that?’ (Jews, you see, don’t have any dealings with Samaritans.)

10.verse: ‘If only you’d known God’s gift,’ replied Jesus, ‘and who it is that’s saying to you, “Give me a drink”, you’d have asked him, and he would have given you living water.’

11.verse: ‘But sir,’ replied the woman, ‘you haven’t got a bucket! And the well’s deep! So how were you thinking of getting living water?

12.verse: Are you greater than our father Jacob, who gave us the well, and drank of it himself, with his sons and his animals?’

13.verse: ‘Everyone who drinks this water’, Jesus replied, ‘will get thirsty again.

14.verse: But anyone who drinks the water I’ll give them won’t ever be thirsty again. No: the water I’ll give them will become a spring of water welling up to the life of God’s new age.’

15.verse: ‘Sir,’ the woman said, ‘give me this water! Then I won’t be thirsty any more, and I won’t have to come here to draw from the well.’

16.verse: Jesus and the Woman - ‘Well then,’ said Jesus to the woman, ‘go and call your husband and come here.’

17.verse: ‘I haven’t got a husband,’ replied the woman. ‘You’re telling me you haven’t got a husband!’ replied Jesus.

18.verse: ‘The fact is, you’ve had five husbands, and the one you’ve got now isn’t your husband. You were speaking the truth!’

19.verse: ‘Well, sir,’ replied the woman, ‘I can see you’re a prophet . . .

20.verse: Our ancestors worshipped on this mountain. And you say that in Jerusalem is the place where people ought to worship.’

21.verse: ‘Believe me, woman,’ replied Jesus, ‘the time is coming when you won’t worship the father on this mountain or in Jerusalem.

22.verse: You worship what you don’t know. We worship what we do know; salvation, you see, is indeed from the Jews.

23.verse: But the time is coming – indeed, it’s here already! – when true worshippers will worship the father in spirit and in truth. Yes; that’s the kind of worshippers the father is looking for.

24.verse: God is spirit, and those who worship him must worship in spirit and in truth.’

25.verse: ‘I know that Messiah is coming,’ said the woman, ‘the one they call “the anointed”. When he comes, he’ll tell us everything.’

26.verse: ‘I’m the one – the one speaking to you right now,’ said Jesus.

27.verse: Sower and Reaper Rejoice Together - Just then Jesus’ disciples came up. They were astonished that he was talking with a woman; but nobody said ‘What did you want?’ or ‘Why were you talking with her?’

28.verse: So the woman left her water-jar, went into the town and spoke to the people.

29.verse: ‘Come on!’ she said. ‘Come and see a man who told me everything I ever did! You don’t think he can be the Messiah, do you?’

30.verse: So they left the town and were coming out to him.

31.verse: Meanwhile the disciples were nagging him. ‘Come on, rabbi!’ they were saying. ‘You must have something to eat!’

32.verse: ‘I’ve got food to eat that you know nothing about,’ he said.

33.verse: ‘Nobody’s brought him anything to eat, have they?’ said the disciples to one another.

34.verse: ‘My food’, replied Jesus, ‘is to do the will of the one who sent me, and to finish his work!

35.verse: Don’t you have a saying, “Another four months, then comes harvest”? Well, let me tell you, raise your eyes and see! The fields are white! It’s harvest time already!

36.verse: The reaper earns his pay, and gathers crops for the life of God’s coming age, so that sower and reaper can celebrate together.

37.verse: This is where that saying comes true, “One sows, another reaps”.

38.verse: I sent you to reap what you didn’t work for. Others did the hard work, and you’ve come into the results.’

39.verse: Several Samaritans from that town believed in Jesus because of what the woman said in evidence about him, ‘He told me everything I did.’

40.verse: So when the Samaritans came to him, they asked him to stay with them. And he stayed there two days.

41.verse: Many more believed because of what he said.

42.verse: ‘We believe, too,’ they said to the woman, ‘but it’s no longer because of what you told us. We’ve heard him ourselves! We know that he really is the one! He’s the saviour of the world!’

43.verse: The Official’s Son - After the two days in Samaria, Jesus went off from there to Galilee.

44.verse: Jesus himself gave evidence, after all, that a prophet isn’t honoured in his own country.

45.verse: So when he came to Galilee, the Galileans welcomed him. They had seen all the things he had done in Jerusalem at the festival, since they had been at the festival too.

46.verse: So he went once more to Cana in Galilee, where he had turned the water into wine. There was a royal official in Capernaum whose son was ill.

47.verse: He heard that Jesus had come from Judaea into Galilee, and he went to him and asked him to come down and heal his son, since he was at the point of death.

48.verse: ‘Unless you see signs and miracles,’ replied Jesus, ‘you won’t ever believe.’

49.verse: ‘Sir,’ replied the official, ‘come down before my child dies!’

50.verse: ‘Off you go!’ said Jesus. ‘Your son will live!’ The man believed the word which Jesus had spoken to him, and he set off.

51.verse: But while he was still on his way down to Capernaum, his servants met him with the news that his son was alive and well.

52.verse: So he asked them what time he had begun to get better. ‘Yesterday afternoon, about one o’clock,’ they said. ‘That’s when the fever left him.’

53.verse: So the father knew that it had happened at the very moment when Jesus had said to him, ‘Your son will live!’ He himself believed, and so did all his household.

54.verse: This was now the second sign Jesus did, when he came out of Judaea into Galilee.

1.verse: The Healing of the Disabled Man - After this there was a Jewish festival, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.

2.verse: In Jerusalem, near the Sheep Gate, there is a pool which is called, in Hebrew, Bethesda. It has five porticoes,

3.verse: where there were several sick people lying. They were blind, lame and paralysed.

4.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

5.verse: There was a man who had been there, in the same sick state, for thirty-eight years.

6.verse: Jesus saw him lying there, and knew that he had been there a long time already. ‘Do you want to get well?’ he asked him.

7.verse: ‘Well, sir,’ the sick man replied, ‘I don’t have anyone to put me into the pool when the water gets stirred up. While I’m on my way there, someone else gets down before me.’

8.verse: ‘Get up,’ said Jesus, ‘pick up your mattress and walk!’

9.verse: At once the man was healed. He picked up his mattress and walked. God’s Son Breaks the Sabbath! - The day all this happened was a sabbath.

10.verse: So the Judaeans confronted the man who had been healed. ‘It’s the sabbath!’ they said. ‘You shouldn’t be carrying your mattress!’

11.verse: ‘Well,’ he replied, ‘the man who cured me told me to pick up my mattress and walk!’

12.verse: ‘Oh, really?’ they said. ‘And who is this man, who told you to pick it up and walk?’

13.verse: But the man who’d been healed didn’t know who it was. Jesus had gone away, and the place was crowded.

14.verse: After this Jesus found the man in the Temple. ‘Look!’ he said. ‘You’re better again! Don’t sin any more, or something worse might happen to you!’

15.verse: The man went off and told the Judaeans that it was Jesus who had healed him.

16.verse: This was why the Judaeans began to persecute Jesus, because he did these things on the sabbath.

17.verse: This was Jesus’ response to them. ‘My father’, he said, ‘is going on working, and so am I!’

18.verse: So for this reason the Judaeans were all the more eager to kill him, because he not only broke the sabbath, but spoke of God as his own father, making himself equal to God.

19.verse: The Coming Judgment - So Jesus made this response to them. ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ he said. ‘The son can do nothing by himself. He can only do what he sees the father doing. Whatever the father does, the son does too, and in the same way.

20.verse: The father loves the son, you see, and shows him all the things that he’s doing. Yes: he will show him even greater things than these, and that’ll amaze you!

21.verse: For, just as the father raises the dead and gives them life, in the same way the son gives life to anyone he chooses.

22.verse: ‘The father doesn’t judge anyone, you see; he has handed over all judgment to the son,

23.verse: so that everyone should honour the son just as they honour the father. Anyone who doesn’t honour the son doesn’t honour the father who sent him.

24.verse: ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth: anyone who hears my word, and believes in the one who sent me, has the life of God’s coming age. Such a person won’t come into judgment; they will have passed out of death into life.

25.verse: I’m telling you the solemn truth: the time is coming – in fact, it’s here already! – when the dead will hear the voice of God’s son, and those who hear it will live.

26.verse: You see, just as the father has life in himself, in the same way he has given the son the privilege of having life in himself.

27.verse: He has even given him authority to pass judgment, because he is the son of man.

28.verse: ‘Don’t be surprised at this. The time is coming, you see, when everyone in the tombs will hear his voice.

29.verse: They will come out – those who have done good, to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil, to the resurrection of judgment.’

30.verse: The Evidence in Support of Jesus - ‘I can’t do anything on my own authority,’ Jesus went on. ‘I judge on the basis of what I hear. And my judgment is just, because I’m not trying to carry out my own wishes, but the wishes of the one who sent me.

31.verse: ‘If I give evidence about myself, my evidence isn’t true.

32.verse: There is someone else who gives evidence about me, and I know that the evidence which he brings about me is true.

33.verse: You sent messengers to John, and he gave evidence about the truth.

34.verse: Not that I need evidence from human beings; but I’m saying this so that you may be saved.

35.verse: ‘John was a burning, bright lamp, and you were happy to celebrate in his light for a while.

36.verse: But I have greater evidence on my side than that of John. The works which the father has given me to complete – these works, which I’m doing, will provide evidence about me, evidence that the father has sent me.

37.verse: And the father who sent me has given evidence about me. You’ve never heard his voice; you’ve never seen his form.

38.verse: What’s more, you haven’t got his word abiding in you, because you don’t believe in the one he sent.’

39.verse: Jesus and Moses - ‘You study the Bible’, Jesus continued, ‘because you suppose that you’ll discover the life of God’s coming age in it. In fact, it’s the Bible which gives evidence about me!

40.verse: But you won’t come to me so that you can have life.

41.verse: ‘I’m not accepting glory from human beings;

42.verse: but I know that you haven’t got the love of God within you.

43.verse: I have come in the name of my father, and you won’t receive me. If someone else comes in his own name, you will receive him!

44.verse: How can you believe, when you receive glory from one another, and you’re not looking for the glory which comes from the one and only God?

45.verse: ‘Don’t think that I’m going to accuse you to the father. There is someone who accuses you: it’s Moses, the one you’ve put your hope in!

46.verse: You see, if you’d believed Moses, you would have believed me – because it was me he was writing about.

47.verse: But if you don’t believe his writings, how are you going to believe my words?’

1.verse: Feeding the Five Thousand - After this Jesus went away to beside the sea of Galilee, that is, the sea of Tiberias.

2.verse: A large crowd followed him, because they saw the signs he was doing in healing the sick.

3.verse: Jesus went up into the mountain and sat down there with his disciples.

4.verse: It was nearly time for the Passover, a Jewish festival.

5.verse: Jesus looked up and saw a great crowd coming to him. ‘Where are we going to buy bread,’ he said to Philip, ‘so that they can have something to eat?’

6.verse: (He said this to test him. He himself knew what he intended to do.)

7.verse: ‘Even with six months’ pay’, replied Philip, ‘you wouldn’t be able to buy enough bread for each of them to have just a little!’

8.verse: One of his disciples, Andrew, Simon Peter’s brother, joined in.

9.verse: ‘There’s a lad here’, he said, ‘who’s got five barley loaves and two fish. But what use are they with this many people?’

10.verse: ‘Make the men sit down,’ said Jesus. There was a lot of grass where they were, so the men sat down, about five thousand in all.

11.verse: So Jesus took the loaves, gave thanks and gave them to the people sitting down, and then did the same with the fish, as much as they wanted.

12.verse: When they were satisfied, he called the disciples. ‘Collect up the bits and pieces left over,’ he said, ‘so that we don’t lose anything.’

13.verse: So they collected it up, and filled twelve baskets with broken pieces of the five barley loaves left behind by the people who had eaten.

14.verse: When the people saw the sign that Jesus had done, they said, ‘This really is the Prophet, the one who is to come into the world.’

15.verse: So when Jesus realized that they were intending to come and seize him to make him king, he withdrew again, by himself, up the mountain.

16.verse: Jesus Walking on the Water - When it was evening, Jesus’ disciples went down to the seashore.

17.verse: They got into a boat, and went across the sea towards Capernaum. It was already getting dark, and Jesus had not yet come to them.

18.verse: A strong wind blew up, and the sea began to get rough.

19.verse: They had been rowing for about three or four miles when they saw Jesus walking on the sea, coming towards the boat. They were terrified.

20.verse: But he spoke to them. ‘It’s me!’ he said. ‘Don’t be afraid!’

21.verse: Then they were eager to take him into the boat; and at once the boat arrived at the land they had been making for.

22.verse: The next day the crowd that had remained on the far side of the lake saw that there had only been the one boat there. They knew that Jesus hadn’t gone with his disciples, but that the disciples had set off by themselves.

23.verse: But other boats came from Tiberias, near the place where they had eaten the bread after the Lord had given thanks.

24.verse: When the crowd saw that neither Jesus nor his disciples were there, they themselves got into the boats and came to Capernaum looking for Jesus.

25.verse: When they found him beside the sea, they said to him, ‘Rabbi, when did you come here?’

26.verse: Bread from Heaven - This was Jesus’ reply. ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ he said. ‘You aren’t looking for me because you saw signs, but because you ate as much bread as you could.

27.verse: You shouldn’t be working for perishable food, but for food that will last to the life of God’s coming age – the food which the son of man will give you, the person whom God the father has stamped with the seal of his approval.’

28.verse: ‘What should we be doing,’ they asked him, ‘so that we can be doing the work God wants?’

29.verse: ‘This is the work God wants of you,’ replied Jesus, ‘that you believe in the one he sent.’

30.verse: ‘Well, then,’ they said to him, ‘what sign are you going to do, so that we can see it and believe you? What work are you doing?

31.verse: Our ancestors ate the manna in the wilderness; it says in the Bible that “he gave them bread from heaven to eat”.’

32.verse: ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ Jesus replied. ‘It wasn’t Moses who gave you the bread from heaven. It was my father who gave you the true bread from heaven.

33.verse: God’s bread, you see, is the one who comes down from heaven and gives life to the world.’

34.verse: ‘Master,’ they said, ‘give us this bread – give it to us always!’

35.verse: ‘I am the bread of life,’ replied Jesus. ‘Anyone who comes to me will never be hungry! Anyone who believes in me will never be thirsty!’

36.verse: The Father’s Will - ‘But I told you’, Jesus continued, ‘that you have indeed seen me – and still you don’t believe!

37.verse: All that the father gives me will come to me; and I won’t reject anyone who comes to me,

38.verse: because I came down from heaven not to do my own will but the will of the one who sent me.

39.verse: And this is the will of the one who sent me, that I should lose nothing out of everything that he has given me, but that I should raise it up on the last day.

40.verse: This is the will of my father, you see: that all who see the son and believe in him should have the life of God’s coming age; and I will raise them up on the last day.’

41.verse: The Judaeans then grumbled about him because he had said, ‘I am the bread which came down from heaven.’

42.verse: ‘Isn’t this Jesus, Joseph’s son?’ they said. ‘We know his father and mother, don’t we? So how can he say “I came down from heaven”?’

44.verse: ‘No one can come to me unless the father who sent me draws them – and I will raise them up on the last day.

45.verse: It is written in the prophets, “They shall all be taught by God.” Everyone who listens to what comes from the father, and learns from it comes to me.

46.verse: Not that anyone has seen the father except the one who is from God; he has seen the father.’

47.verse: Eating and Drinking the Son of Man - ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ Jesus went on. ‘Anyone who believes in me has the life of God’s coming age.

48.verse: I am the bread of life.

49.verse: Your ancestors in the wilderness ate the manna, and they died.

50.verse: This is the bread which comes down from heaven, so that people can eat it and not die.

51.verse: I am the living bread which came down from heaven. If anyone eats from this bread, they will live for ever. And the bread which I shall give is my flesh, given for the life of the world.’

52.verse: This caused a squabble among the Judaeans. ‘How can this fellow give us his flesh to eat?’ they asked.

53.verse: ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ Jesus replied. ‘If you don’t eat the flesh of the son of man, and drink his blood, you have no life in yourselves.

54.verse: Anyone who feasts upon my flesh and drinks my blood has the life of God’s coming age, and I will raise them up on the last day.

55.verse: My flesh is true food, you see, and my blood is true drink.

56.verse: Anyone who eats my flesh and drinks my blood remains in me, and I remain in them.

57.verse: Just as the living father sent me, and I live because of the father, so the one who eats me will live because of me.

58.verse: This is the bread which came down from heaven; it isn’t like the bread which the ancestors ate, and died. The one who eats this bread will share the life of God’s new age.’

59.verse: He said this in the synagogue, while he was teaching in Capernaum.

60.verse: Division among Jesus’ Followers - When they heard this, many of Jesus’ disciples said, ‘This is difficult stuff! Who can bear to listen to it?’

61.verse: Jesus knew in himself that his disciples were grumbling about what he’d said. ‘Does this put you off?’ he said.

62.verse: ‘What if you were to see the son of man ascending to where he was before?

63.verse: It’s the spirit that gives life; the flesh is no help. The words that I have spoken to you – they are spirit, they are life.

64.verse: But there are some of you who don’t believe.’ Jesus knew from the beginning, you see, those who didn’t believe, and the one who was going to betray him.

65.verse: ‘That’s why I said’, he went on, ‘that no one can come to me unless it is given to them by the father.’

66.verse: From that time on, several of his disciples drew back, and no longer went about with him.

67.verse: Jesus turned to the Twelve. ‘You don’t want to go away too, do you?’ he asked.

68.verse: Simon Peter spoke up. ‘Master,’ he said, ‘who can we go to? You’re the one who’s got the words of the life of the coming age!

69.verse: We’ve come to believe it – we’ve come to know it! – that you are God’s holy one.’

70.verse: ‘Well,’ replied Jesus, ‘I chose you twelve, didn’t I? And one of you is an accuser!’

71.verse: He was referring to Judas, son of Simon Iscariot. He was one of the Twelve, and he was going to betray him.

1.verse: Jesus and His Brothers - After this, Jesus went about in Galilee. He didn’t want to go about in Judaea, because the Judaeans were after his blood.

2.verse: The time came for the Jewish festival of Tabernacles.

3.verse: So Jesus’ brothers approached him. ‘Leave this place’, they said, ‘and go to Judaea! Then your disciples will see the works you’re doing.

4.verse: Nobody who wants to become well known does things in secret. If you’re doing these things, show yourself to the world!’

5.verse: Even his brothers, you see, didn’t believe in him.

6.verse: ‘My time isn’t here yet,’ replied Jesus, ‘but your time is always here.

7.verse: The world can’t hate you, but it hates me, because I am giving evidence against it, showing that its works are evil.

8.verse: I tell you what: you go up to the feast. I’m not going up to this feast; my time is not yet complete.’

9.verse: With these words, he stayed behind in Galilee.

10.verse: Disputes about Jesus - But when Jesus’ brothers had gone up to the festival, then he himself went up, not openly, but, so to speak, in secret.

11.verse: The Judaeans were looking for him at the feast. ‘Where is he?’ they were saying.

12.verse: There was considerable dispute about him among the crowds. ‘He’s a good man!’ some were saying. ‘No, he isn’t,’ others would reply. ‘He’s deceiving the people!’

13.verse: But nobody dared speak about him openly, for fear of the Judaeans.

14.verse: About the middle of the feast, Jesus went up into the Temple and began to teach.

15.verse: The Judaeans were astonished. ‘Where does this fellow get all his learning from?’ they asked. ‘He’s never been trained!’

16.verse: ‘My teaching isn’t my own,’ replied Jesus. ‘It comes from the one who sent me!

17.verse: If anyone wants to do what God wants, they will know whether this teaching is from God, or whether I’m just speaking on my own account.

18.verse: Anyone who speaks on his own behalf is trying to establish his own reputation. But if what he’s interested in is the reputation of the one who sent him, then he is true, and there is no injustice in him.’

19.verse: Moses and the Messiah - ‘Moses gave you the law, didn’t he?’ Jesus continued. ‘But none of you obeys the law. Why are you wanting to kill me?’

20.verse: The crowd responded to this. ‘You must have a demon inside you!’ they said. ‘Who is trying to kill you?’

21.verse: ‘Look here,’ replied Jesus. ‘I did one single thing, and you are all amazed.

22.verse: Moses commanded you to practise circumcision (not that it starts with Moses, of course; it comes from the patriarchs), and you circumcise a man on the sabbath.

23.verse: Well, then, if a man receives circumcision on the sabbath, so that the law of Moses may not be broken, how can you be angry with me if I make an entire man healthy on the sabbath?

24.verse: Don’t judge by appearances! Judge with proper and right judgment!’

25.verse: Some Jerusalem residents commented, ‘Isn’t this the man they’re trying to kill?

26.verse: Look – he’s speaking quite openly, and nobody is saying anything to him. You don’t suppose our rulers really know he’s the Messiah, do you?

27.verse: The thing is, we know where he comes from – but when the Messiah appears, nobody will know where he comes from.’

28.verse: As Jesus was teaching in the Temple, he shouted out, ‘You know me! You know where I come from! I haven’t come on my own behalf – but the one who sent me is true, and you don’t know him!

29.verse: I know him, because I come from him, and he sent me!’

30.verse: So they tried to arrest him. But nobody laid hands on him, because his time had not yet come.

31.verse: Rivers of Living Water - Many people from the crowd believed in Jesus. ‘When the Messiah comes,’ they were saying, ‘will he do more signs than this man has done?’

32.verse: The Pharisees heard that the crowd was full of this rumour about him, and the chief priests and Pharisees sent servants to arrest him.

33.verse: So Jesus said, ‘I’m just with you for a little while, and then I’m going to the one who sent me.

34.verse: You will look for me and you won’t find me, and you can’t come where I am.’

35.verse: ‘Where does he think he’s going,’ said the Judaeans to one another, ‘if we won’t be able to find him? He’s not going to go off abroad, among the Greeks, is he, and teach the Greeks?

36.verse: What does he mean when he says, “You’ll look for me and you won’t find me”, and “Where I am, you can’t come”?’

37.verse: On the last day of the festival, the great final celebration, Jesus stood up and shouted out, ‘If anybody’s thirsty, they should come to me and have a drink!

38.verse: Anyone who believes in me will have rivers of living water flowing out of their heart, just like the Bible says!’

39.verse: He said this about the spirit, which people who believed in him were to receive. The spirit wasn’t available yet, because Jesus was not yet glorified.

40.verse: Where Does the Messiah Come From? - When they heard these words, some people in the crowd said, ‘This man really is “the Prophet”!’

41.verse: ‘He’s the Messiah!’ said some others. But some of them replied, ‘The Messiah doesn’t come from Galilee, does he?

42.verse: Doesn’t the Bible say that the Messiah is descended from David, and comes from Bethlehem, the city where David was?’

43.verse: So there was a division in the crowd because of him.

44.verse: Some of them wanted to arrest him, but nobody laid hands on him.

45.verse: So the servants went back to the chief priests and the Pharisees. ‘Why didn’t you get him?’ they asked.

46.verse: ‘No man ever spoke like this!’ the servants replied.

47.verse: ‘You don’t mean to say you’ve been taken in too?’ answered the Pharisees.

48.verse: ‘None of the rulers or the Pharisees have believed in him, have they?

49.verse: But this rabble that doesn’t know the law – a curse on them!’

50.verse: Nicodemus, who went to Jesus earlier, and who was one of their own number, spoke up.

51.verse: ‘Our law doesn’t condemn a man, does it, unless first you hear his side of the story and find out what he’s doing?’

52.verse: ‘Oh, so you’re from Galilee too, are you?’ they answered him. ‘Check it out and see! No prophet ever rises up from Galilee!’

53.verse: Adultery and Hypocrisy - They all went off home,

1.verse: and Jesus went to the Mount of Olives.

2.verse: In the morning he went back to the Temple. All the people came to him, and he sat down and taught them.

3.verse: The scribes and Pharisees brought a woman who had been caught out in adultery. They stood her out in the middle.

4.verse: ‘Teacher,’ they said to him. ‘This woman was caught in the very act of adultery.

5.verse: In the law, Moses commanded us to stone people like this. What do you say?’

6.verse: They said this to test him, so that they could frame a charge against him. Jesus squatted down and wrote with his finger on the ground.

7.verse: When they went on pressing the question, he got up and said to them, ‘Whichever of you is without sin should throw the first stone at her.’

8.verse: And once again he squatted down and wrote on the ground.

9.verse: When they heard that, they went off one by one, beginning with the oldest. Jesus was left alone, with the woman still standing there.

10.verse: Jesus looked up. ‘Where are they, woman?’ he asked. ‘Hasn’t anybody condemned you?’

11.verse: ‘Nobody, sir,’ she replied. ‘Well, then,’ said Jesus, ‘I don’t condemn you either! Off you go – and from now on don’t sin again!’

12.verse: The Light of the World - Jesus spoke to them again. ‘I am the light of the world,’ he said. ‘People who follow me won’t go around in the dark; they’ll have the light of life!’

13.verse: ‘You’re giving evidence in your own case!’ said the Pharisees. ‘Your evidence is false!’

14.verse: ‘Even if I do give evidence about myself,’ replied Jesus to them, ‘my evidence is true, because I know where I came from and where I’m going to. But you don’t know where I come from or where I’m going to.

15.verse: You are judging in merely human terms; I don’t judge anyone.

16.verse: But even if I do judge, my judgment is true, because I’m not a lone voice; I have on my side the father who sent me.

17.verse: It is written in your law that the evidence of two people is true.

18.verse: I’m giving evidence about myself, and the father who sent me is giving evidence about me.’

19.verse: ‘Where is your father?’ they said to him. ‘You don’t know me,’ replied Jesus, ‘and you don’t know my father! If you had known me, you would have known my father as well.’

20.verse: He said all this in the treasury, while he was teaching in the Temple. Nobody arrested him, though, because his time hadn’t yet come.

21.verse: From Below or from Above - So Jesus spoke to them once more. ‘I am going away,’ he said. ‘You will look for me, and you will die in your sin. You can’t come where I’m going.’

22.verse: ‘Is he going to kill himself?’ asked the Judaeans. ‘Is that what he means when he says we can’t come where he’s going?’

23.verse: ‘You come from below,’ Jesus said to them, ‘but I come from above. You are from this world, I am not from this world.

24.verse: I told you that you would die in your sins; you see, that’s what will happen to you if you don’t believe that I am the one.’

25.verse: ‘Who are you?’ they asked. ‘What I’ve been telling you from the beginning,’ replied Jesus.

26.verse: ‘There are plenty of things I could say about you, yes, and against you too! But the one who sent me is true, and I tell the world what I heard from him.’

27.verse: They didn’t understand that he was talking about the father.

28.verse: So Jesus said to them, ‘When you’ve lifted up the son of man, then you will know that I’m the one, and that I never act on my own initiative; I say exactly what the father taught me.

29.verse: And the one who sent me is with me. He hasn’t left me alone, because I always do what pleases him.’

30.verse: The Truth Will Make You Free - As Jesus said all this, several people believed in him.

31.verse: So Jesus spoke to the Judaeans who had believed in him. ‘If you remain in my word,’ he said, ‘you will truly be my disciples,

32.verse: and you will know the truth, and the truth will make you free.’

33.verse: ‘We are Abraham’s descendants!’ they replied. ‘We’ve never been anyone’s slaves! How can you say that “You’ll become free”?’

34.verse: ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ Jesus replied. ‘Everyone who commits sin is a slave of sin.

35.verse: The slave doesn’t live in the house for ever; the son lives there for ever.

36.verse: So, you see, if the son makes you free, you will be truly free.’

37.verse: Children of Abraham – or of the Devil - ‘I know you’re Abraham’s descendants,’ Jesus went on. ‘But you’re trying to kill me, because my word doesn’t find a place among you.

38.verse: I am speaking of what I have seen with the father; and you, too, are doing what you heard from your father.’

39.verse: ‘Abraham is our father!’ they replied. ‘If you really were Abraham’s children,’ replied Jesus, ‘you would do what Abraham did!

40.verse: But now you’re trying to kill me – me, a man who has told you the truth which I heard from God! That’s not what Abraham did.

41.verse: You’re doing the works of your father.’ ‘There wasn’t anything immoral about the way we were born!’ they replied. ‘We’ve got one father, and that’s God!’

42.verse: ‘If God really was your father,’ replied Jesus, ‘you would love me, because I came from God, and here I am. I didn’t come on my own initiative, you see, but he sent me.

43.verse: Why don’t you understand what I’m saying? It can only be because you can’t hear my word.

44.verse: You are from your father – the devil! And you’re eager to get on with what he wants. He was a murderer from the beginning, and he’s never remained in the truth, because there is no truth in him. When he tells lies, he speaks what comes naturally to him, because he is a liar – in fact, he’s the father of lies!

45.verse: But because I speak the truth, you don’t believe me.

46.verse: Which of you can bring a charge of sin against me? If I speak the truth, why don’t you believe me?

47.verse: The one who is from God speaks God’s words. That’s why you don’t listen, because you’re not from God.’

48.verse: Before Abraham, ‘I Am’ - This was the Judaeans’ response to Jesus. ‘Haven’t we been right all along,’ they said, ‘in saying you’re a Samaritan, and that you’ve got a demon inside you?’

49.verse: ‘I haven’t got a demon!’ replied Jesus. ‘I am honouring my father, and you are dishonouring me.

50.verse: I’m not looking for my own glory; there is one who is looking after that, and he will be the judge.

51.verse: I’m telling you the solemn truth: anyone who keeps my word will never, ever see death.’

52.verse: ‘Now we know that you really have got a demon!’ replied the Judaeans. ‘Look here: Abraham died! So did the prophets! And here are you, saying, “Anyone who keeps my word will never, ever taste death.”

53.verse: You’re not suggesting, are you, that you’re greater than our father Abraham? He died, and so did the prophets! Who are you making yourself out to be?’

54.verse: ‘If I do give myself glory,’ replied Jesus, ‘my glory is nothing. My father is the one who brings me glory – the one you say is “our God”;

55.verse: and you don’t know him! I know him, though. If I were to say I didn’t know him, I would be a liar like you. But I do know him, and I keep his word.

56.verse: Your father Abraham celebrated the fact that he would see my day. He saw it and was delighted.’

57.verse: ‘You’re not yet fifty years old!’ responded the Judaeans. ‘Have you seen Abraham?’

58.verse: ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ replied Jesus. ‘Before Abraham existed, I Am.’

59.verse: So they picked up stones to throw at him. But Jesus hid, and left the Temple.

1.verse: The Man Born Blind - As Jesus was going along, he saw a man who had been blind from birth.

2.verse: ‘Teacher,’ his disciples asked him, ‘whose sin was it that caused this man to be born blind? Did he sin, or did his parents?’

3.verse: ‘He didn’t sin,’ replied Jesus, ‘nor did his parents. It happened so that God’s works could be seen in him.

4.verse: We must work the works of the one who sent me as long as it’s still daytime. The night is coming, and nobody can work then!

5.verse: As long as I’m in the world, I’m the light of the world.’

6.verse: With these words, he spat on the ground, and made some mud out of his spittle. He spread the mud on the man’s eyes.

7.verse: ‘Off you go’, he said to him, ‘and wash in the pool of Siloam’ (which means ‘sent’). So he went off and washed. When he came back, he could see.

8.verse: His neighbours, and the people who used to see him begging, remarked on this. ‘Isn’t this the man’, they said, ‘who used to sit here and beg?’

9.verse: ‘Yes, it’s him!’ said some of them. ‘No, it isn’t!’ said some others. ‘It’s somebody like him.’ But the man himself spoke. ‘Yes, it’s me,’ he said.

10.verse: ‘Well, then,’ they said to him, ‘how did your eyes get opened?’

11.verse: ‘It was the man called Jesus!’ he replied. ‘He made some mud, then he spread it on my eyes, and told me to go to Siloam and wash. So I went, and washed, and I could see!’

12.verse: ‘Where is he?’ they asked. ‘I don’t know,’ he replied.

13.verse: The Blind Man’s Parents - They took the man who had been blind and brought him to the Pharisees.

14.verse: ( The day Jesus had made the mud, and opened his eyes, was a sabbath.)

15.verse: So the Pharisees began to ask him again how he had come to see. ‘He put some mud on my eyes,’ he said, ‘and I washed, and now I can see!’

16.verse: ‘The man can’t be from God,’ some of the Pharisees began to say. ‘He doesn’t keep the sabbath!’ ‘Well, but,’ replied some of the others, ‘how can a man who is a sinner do signs like these?’ And they were divided.

17.verse: So they spoke to the blind man again. ‘What have you got to say about him?’ they asked. ‘He opened your eyes, after all.’ ‘He’s a prophet,’ he replied.

18.verse: The Judaeans didn’t believe that he really had been blind and now could see. So they called the parents of the newly sighted man,

19.verse: and put the question to them. ‘Is this man really your son,’ they asked, ‘the one you say was born blind? How is it that he can now see?’

20.verse: ‘Well,’ replied his parents, ‘we know that he is indeed our son, and that he was born blind.

21.verse: But we don’t know how it is that he can now see, and we don’t know who it was that opened his eyes. Ask him! He’s grown up. He can speak for himself.’

22.verse: His parents said this because they were afraid of the Judaeans. The Judaeans, you see, had already decided that if anyone declared that Jesus was the Messiah, they should be put out of the synagogue.

23.verse: That’s why his parents said, ‘He’s grown up, so you should ask him.’

24.verse: Is Jesus from God? - So for the second time they called the man who had been blind. ‘Give God the glory!’ they said. ‘We know that this man is a sinner.’

25.verse: ‘I don’t know whether he’s a sinner or not,’ replied the man. ‘All I know is this: I used to be blind, and now I can see.’

26.verse: ‘What did he do to you?’ they asked. ‘How did he open your eyes?’

27.verse: ‘I told you already,’ replied the man, ‘and you didn’t listen. Why d’you want to hear it again? You don’t want to become his disciples too, do you?’

28.verse: ‘You’re his disciple,’ they scoffed, ‘but we are Moses’s disciples.

29.verse: We know that God spoke to Moses, but we don’t know where this man comes from.’

30.verse: ‘Well, here’s a fine thing!’ replied the man. ‘You don’t know where he’s from, and he opened my eyes!

31.verse: We know that God doesn’t listen to sinners; but if anyone is devout, and does his will, he listens to them.

32.verse: It’s never, ever been heard of before that someone should open the eyes of a person born blind.

33.verse: If this man wasn’t from God, he couldn’t do anything.’

34.verse: ‘You were born in sin from top to toe,’ they replied, ‘and are you going to start teaching us?’ And they threw him out.

35.verse: Seeing and Not Seeing - Jesus heard that they had thrown the man out. He found him and spoke to him. ‘Do you believe in the son of man?’ he asked.

36.verse: ‘Who is he, sir,’ asked the man, ‘so that I can believe in him?’

37.verse: ‘You have seen him,’ replied Jesus. ‘In fact, it’s the person who’s talking to you.’

38.verse: ‘Yes, sir,’ said the man; ‘I do believe.’ And he worshipped him.

39.verse: ‘I came into the world for judgment,’ said Jesus, ‘so that those who can’t see would see, and so that those who can see would become blind.’

40.verse: Some of the Pharisees were nearby, and they heard this. ‘So!’ they said. ‘We’re blind too, are we?’

41.verse: ‘If you were blind,’ replied Jesus, ‘you wouldn’t be guilty of sin. But now, because you say, “We can see”, your sin remains.’

1.verse: The Good Shepherd - ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ said Jesus. ‘Anyone who doesn’t come into the sheepfold by the gate, but gets in by some other way, is a thief and a brigand.

2.verse: But the one who comes in through the gate is the sheep’s own shepherd.

3.verse: The doorkeeper will open up for him, and the sheep hear his voice. He calls his own sheep by name, and leads them out.

4.verse: When he has brought out all that belong to him, he goes on ahead of them. The sheep follow him, because they know his voice.

5.verse: They won’t follow a stranger; instead, they will run away from him, because they don’t know the stranger’s voice.’

6.verse: Jesus spoke this parable to them, but they didn’t understand what it was he was saying to them.

7.verse: So he spoke to them again. ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ he said. ‘I am the gate of the sheep.

8.verse: All the people who came before me were thieves and brigands, but the sheep didn’t listen to them.

9.verse: I am the gate. If anyone comes in by me, they will be safe, and will go in and out and find pasture.

10.verse: The thief only comes to steal, and kill, and destroy. I came so that they could have life – yes, and have it full to overflowing.’

11.verse: The Shepherd and the Sheep - ‘I am the good shepherd,’ Jesus continued. ‘The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.

12.verse: But supposing there’s a hired servant, who isn’t himself the shepherd, and who doesn’t himself own the sheep. He will see the wolf coming, and leave the sheep, and run away. Then the wolf will snatch the sheep and scatter them.

13.verse: He’ll run away because he’s only a hired servant, and doesn’t care about the sheep.

14.verse: ‘I am the good shepherd. I know my own sheep, and my own know me –

15.verse: just as the father knows me and I know the father. And I lay down my life for the sheep.

16.verse: And I have other sheep, too, which don’t belong to this sheepfold. I must bring them, too, and they will hear my voice. Then there will be one flock, and one shepherd.

17.verse: ‘That’s why the father loves me, because I lay down my life, so that I can take it again.

18.verse: Nobody takes it from me; I lay it down of my own accord. I have the right to lay it down, and I have the right to receive it back again. This is the command I received from my father.’

19.verse: The Messiah and the Father - So there was again a division among the Judaeans because of what Jesus had said.

20.verse: ‘He’s demon-possessed!’ some were saying. ‘He’s raving mad! Why listen to him?’

21.verse: ‘No,’ said some others, ‘that’s not how demon-possessed people talk. Anyway, how could a demon open a blind man’s eyes?’

22.verse: It was the Feast of the Dedication in Jerusalem. It was winter,

23.verse: and Jesus was walking in the Temple, in Solomon’s Porch.

24.verse: The Judaeans surrounded him. ‘How much longer are you going to keep us in suspense?’ they asked. ‘If you are the Messiah, say so out loud!’

25.verse: ‘I told you,’ replied Jesus, ‘and you didn’t believe. The works which I’m doing in my father’s name give evidence about me.

26.verse: But you don’t believe, because you don’t belong to my sheep.

27.verse: ‘My sheep hear my voice. I know them, and they follow me.

28.verse: I give them the life of the coming age. They will never, ever perish, and nobody can snatch them out of my hand.

29.verse: My father, who has given them to me, is greater than all, and nobody can snatch them out of my father’s hand.

30.verse: I and the father are one.’

31.verse: Blasphemy! - So the Judaeans once more picked up stones to stone him.

32.verse: ‘I’ve shown you many fine deeds from the father,’ Jesus replied to them. ‘Which of these deeds are you stoning me for?’

33.verse: ‘We’re not stoning you for good deeds,’ replied the Judaeans, ‘but because of blasphemy! Here you are, a mere man, and you’re making yourself into God!’

34.verse: ‘It’s written in your law, isn’t it,’ replied Jesus to them, ‘ “I said, you are gods?”

35.verse: Well, if the law calls people “gods”, people to whom God’s word came (and you can’t set the Bible aside),

36.verse: how can you accuse someone of blasphemy when the father has placed him apart and sent him into the world, and he says, “I am the son of God”?

37.verse: ‘If I’m not doing the works of my father, don’t believe me.

38.verse: But if I am doing them, well – even if you don’t believe me, believe the works! That way you will know and grasp that the father is in me, and I am in the father.’

39.verse: So again they tried to arrest him. But Jesus managed to get away from them.

40.verse: He went off once more across the Jordan, to the place where John had been baptizing at the beginning, and he stayed there.

41.verse: Several people came to him. ‘John never did any signs,’ they said, ‘but everything that John said about this man was true.’

42.verse: And many believed in him there.

1.verse: The Death of Lazarus - There was a man in Bethany named Lazarus, and he became ill. Bethany was the village of Mary and her sister Martha.

2.verse: ( This was the Mary who anointed the Lord with myrrh, and wiped his feet with her hair; Lazarus, who was ill, was her brother.)

3.verse: So the sisters sent messengers to Jesus. ‘Master,’ they said, ‘the man you love is ill.’

4.verse: When Jesus got the message, he said, ‘This illness won’t lead to death. It’s all about the glory of God! The son of God will be glorified through it.’

5.verse: Now Jesus loved Martha, and her sister, and Lazarus.

6.verse: So when he heard that he was ill, he stayed where he was, to begin with, for two days.

7.verse: Then, after that, he said to the disciples, ‘Let’s go back to Judaea.’

8.verse: ‘Teacher,’ replied the disciples, ‘the Judaeans were trying to stone you just now! Surely you don’t want to go back there!’

9.verse: ‘There are twelve hours in the day, aren’t there?’ replied Jesus. ‘If you walk in the day, you won’t trip up, because you’ll see the light of this world.

10.verse: But if anyone walks in the night, they will trip up, because there is no light in them.’

11.verse: When he had said this, Jesus added: ‘Our friend Lazarus has fallen asleep. But I’m going to wake him up.’

12.verse: ‘Master,’ replied the disciples, ‘if he’s asleep, he’ll be all right.’

13.verse: ( They thought he was referring to ordinary sleep; but Jesus had in fact been speaking of his death.)

14.verse: Then Jesus spoke to them plainly. ‘Lazarus’, he said, ‘is dead.

15.verse: Actually, I’m glad I wasn’t there, for your sakes; it will help your faith. But let’s go to him.’

16.verse: Thomas, whose name was the Twin, addressed the other disciples. ‘Let’s go too,’ he said. ‘We may as well die with him.’

17.verse: The Resurrection and the Life - So when Jesus arrived, he found that Lazarus had already been in the tomb for four days.

18.verse: Bethany was near Jerusalem, about two miles away.

19.verse: Many of the Judaeans had come to Martha and Mary to console them about their brother.

20.verse: When Martha heard that Jesus had arrived, she went to meet him. Mary, meanwhile, stayed sitting at home.

21.verse: ‘Master!’ said Martha to Jesus. ‘If only you’d been here! Then my brother wouldn’t have died!

22.verse: But even now I know that God will give you whatever you ask him for.’

23.verse: ‘Your brother will rise again,’ replied Jesus.

24.verse: ‘I know he’ll rise again,’ said Martha, ‘in the resurrection on the last day.’

25.verse: ‘I am the resurrection and the life,’ replied Jesus. ‘Anyone who believes in me will live, even if they die.

26.verse: And anyone who lives and believes in me will never, ever die. Do you believe this?’

27.verse: ‘Yes, Master,’ she said. ‘This is what I’ve come to believe: that you are the Messiah, the son of God, the one who was to come into the world.’

28.verse: Jesus Goes to the Tomb - With these words, Martha went back and called her sister Mary. ‘The teacher has come,’ she said to her privately, ‘and he’s asking for you.’

29.verse: When she heard that, she got up quickly and went to him.

30.verse: Jesus hadn’t yet got into the village. He was still in the place where Martha had met him.

31.verse: The Judaeans who were in the house with Mary, consoling her, saw her get up quickly and go out. They guessed that she was going to the tomb to weep there, and they followed her.

32.verse: When Mary came to where Jesus was, she saw him and fell down at his feet. ‘Master!’ she said. ‘If only you’d been here, my brother wouldn’t have died!’

33.verse: When Jesus saw her crying, and the Judaeans who had come with her crying, he was deeply stirred in his spirit, and very troubled.

34.verse: ‘Where have you laid him?’ he asked. ‘Master,’ they said, ‘come and see.’

36.verse: ‘Look,’ said the Judaeans, ‘see how much he loved him!’

37.verse: ‘Well, yes,’ some of them said, ‘but he opened the eyes of a blind man, didn’t he? Couldn’t he have done something to stop this fellow from dying?’

38.verse: The Raising of Lazarus - Jesus was once again deeply troubled within himself. He came to the tomb. It was a cave, and a stone was placed in front of it.

39.verse: ‘Take away the stone,’ said Jesus. ‘But, Master,’ said Martha, the dead man’s sister, ‘there’ll be a smell! It’s the fourth day already!’

40.verse: ‘Didn’t I tell you’, said Jesus, ‘that if you believed you would see God’s glory?’

41.verse: So they took the stone away. Jesus lifted up his eyes. ‘Thank you, father,’ he said, ‘for hearing me!

42.verse: I know you always hear me, but I’ve said this because of the crowd standing around, so that they may believe that you sent me.’

43.verse: With these words, he gave a loud shout: ‘Lazarus – come out!’

44.verse: And the dead man came out. He was tied up, hand and foot, with strips of linen, and his face was wrapped in a cloth. ‘Untie him,’ said Jesus, ‘and let him go.’

45.verse: The result of all this was that several of the Judaeans who had come to Mary, and who had seen what he had done, believed in him.

46.verse: But some of them went off to the Pharisees and told them what Jesus had done.

47.verse: The Plan of Caiaphas - So the chief priests and the Pharisees called an assembly. ‘What are we going to do?’ they asked. ‘This man is performing lots of signs.

48.verse: If we let him go on like this, everyone is going to believe in him! Then the Romans will come and take away our holy place, and our nation!’

49.verse: But one of them, Caiaphas, the high priest that year, addressed them. ‘You know nothing at all!’ he said.

50.verse: ‘You haven’t worked it out! This is what’s best for you: let one man die for the people, rather than the whole nation being wiped out.’

51.verse: He didn’t say this of his own accord. Since he was high priest that year, it was a prophecy. It meant that Jesus would die for the nation;

52.verse: and not only for the nation, but to gather into one the scattered children of God.

53.verse: So from that day on they plotted how to kill him.

54.verse: So Jesus didn’t go around openly any longer among the Judaeans. He went away from there to the region by the desert, to a town called Ephraim. He stayed there with the disciples.

55.verse: The time came for the Judaeans’ Passover. Lots of people went up to Jerusalem from the countryside, before the Passover, to purify themselves.

56.verse: They were looking for Jesus. As they stood there in the Temple, they were discussing him with one another. ‘What d’you think?’ they were saying. ‘Do you suppose he won’t come to the festival?’

57.verse: The chief priests and the Pharisees had given the order that if anyone knew where he was, they should tell them, so that they could arrest him.

1.verse: Mary and Her Ointment - Six days before the Passover, Jesus came to Bethany. Lazarus was there, the man he had raised from the dead.

2.verse: So they made a dinner for him there. Martha served, and Lazarus was among the company at table with him.

3.verse: Then Mary took a pound of very expensive perfume, made of pure nard. She anointed Jesus’ feet with it, and wiped his feet with her hair. The house was filled with the smell of the perfume.

4.verse: At this, Judas Iscariot, one of his disciples (the one who was going to betray him), spoke up.

5.verse: ‘Why wasn’t this ointment sold?’ he asked. ‘It would have fetched a year’s wages! You could have given it to the poor!’

6.verse: ( He didn’t say this because he cared for the poor, but because he was a thief. He kept the common purse, and used to help himself to what was in it.)

7.verse: ‘Let her alone,’ replied Jesus. ‘She’s been keeping it for the day of my burial!

8.verse: You always have the poor with you, but you won’t always have me.’

9.verse: Jesus Enters Jerusalem - When the great crowd of Judaeans discovered that Jesus was there, they came to Bethany not just because of Jesus, but to see Lazarus, the one he had raised from the dead.

10.verse: So the chief priests planned to kill Lazarus as well,

11.verse: because many of the Judaeans were leaving their side on account of him, and were believing in Jesus.

12.verse: On the next day, the large crowd that had come up for the festival heard that Jesus had come to Jerusalem.

13.verse: They took palm branches and went out to meet him. ‘Hosanna!’ they shouted. ‘Welcome in the name of the Lord! Welcome to Israel’s king!’

14.verse: Jesus found a little donkey and sat on it. As the Bible says,

15.verse: Do not fear, daughter of Zion! Look! Your king is coming now; sitting on a donkey’s colt.

16.verse: His disciples didn’t understand this to begin with. But when Jesus was glorified, they remembered that these things had been written about him, and that these things had been done to him.

17.verse: The crowd that was with him when he called Lazarus out of the tomb, and raised him from the dead, told their story.

18.verse: That’s why the crowd went out to meet him, because they heard that he had done this sign.

19.verse: The Pharisees conferred. ‘You see?’ they said to each other. ‘It’s impossible. There’s nothing you can do. Look – the world has gone off after him!’

20.verse: The Seed Must Die - Some Greeks had come up with all the others to worship at the festival.

21.verse: They went to Philip, who was from Bethsaida in Galilee. ‘Sir,’ they said, ‘we would like to see Jesus.’

22.verse: Philip went and told Andrew, and Andrew and Philip went together to tell Jesus.

23.verse: ‘The time has come,’ said Jesus in reply. ‘This is the moment for the son of man to be glorified.

24.verse: I’m telling you the solemn truth: unless a grain of wheat falls into the earth and dies, it remains all by itself. If it dies, though, it will produce lots of fruit.

25.verse: If you love your life, you’ll lose it. If you hate your life in this world, you’ll keep it for the life of the coming age.

26.verse: ‘If anyone serves me, they must follow me. Where I am, my servant will be too. If anyone serves me, the father will honour them.’

27.verse: The Hour Has Come - ‘Now my heart is troubled,’ Jesus went on. ‘What am I going to say? “Father, save me from this moment?” No! It was because of this that I came to this moment.

28.verse: Father, glorify your name!’ ‘I have glorified it,’ came a voice from heaven, ‘and I will glorify it again.’

29.verse: ‘That was thunder!’ said the crowd, standing there listening. ‘No,’ said others. ‘It was an angel, talking to him.’

30.verse: ‘That voice came for your sake, not mine,’ replied Jesus.

31.verse: ‘Now comes the judgment of this world! Now this world’s ruler is going to be thrown out!

32.verse: And when I’ve been lifted up from the earth, I will draw all people to myself.’

33.verse: He said this in order to point to the kind of death he was going to die.

34.verse: So the crowd spoke to him again. ‘We heard in the law’, they said, ‘that the Messiah will last for ever. How can you say that the son of man must be lifted up? Who is this “son of man”?’

35.verse: ‘The light is among you a little while longer,’ replied Jesus. ‘Keep walking while you have the light, in case the darkness overcomes you. People who walk in the dark don’t know where they’re going.

36.verse: While you have the light, believe in the light, so that you may be children of light.’ With these words, Jesus went away and was hidden from them.

37.verse: Glory and Blindness - They didn’t believe in him, even though he had done so many signs in front of their eyes.

38.verse: This was so that the word of Isaiah the prophet might be fulfilled: Lord, who believed the story we told? Your powerful arm – who saw it unveiled?

39.verse: That’s why they couldn’t believe. As Isaiah again put it,

40.verse: He has caused their eyes to be blind, and caused their hearts to be hard; so they wouldn’t see with their eyes, or understand with their hearts, or turn, so that I could heal them.

41.verse: Isaiah said this because he saw his glory, and spoke about him.

42.verse: Even so, however, quite a few of the rulers did believe in him. But, because of the Pharisees, they didn’t declare their faith, for fear of being put out of the synagogue.

43.verse: This was because they loved the praise of other people more than the praise of God.

44.verse: The Final Challenge - ‘Anyone who believes in me’, shouted Jesus in a loud voice, ‘doesn’t believe in me, but in the one who sent me!

45.verse: Anyone who sees me sees the one who sent me!

46.verse: I’ve come into the world as light, so that everyone who believes in me won’t need to stay in the dark.

47.verse: ‘If anyone hears my words and doesn’t keep them, I’m not going to judge them. That wasn’t why I came. I came to save the world, not to judge it.

48.verse: Anyone who rejects me and doesn’t hold on to my words has a judge. The word which I have spoken will judge them on the last day.

49.verse: ‘I haven’t spoken on my own authority. The father who sent me gave me his own command about what I should say and speak.

50.verse: And I know that his command is the life of the coming age. What I speak, then, is what the father has told me to speak.’

1.verse: Washing the Disciples’ Feet - It was before the festival of Passover. Jesus knew that his time had come, the time for him to leave this world and go to the father. He had always loved his own people in the world; now he loved them right through to the end.

2.verse: It was supper-time. The devil had already put the idea of betraying him into the heart of Judas, son of Simon Iscariot.

3.verse: Jesus knew that the father had given everything into his hands, and that he had come from God and was going to God.

4.verse: So he got up from the supper-table, took off his clothes, and wrapped a towel around himself.

5.verse: Then he poured water into a bowl, and began to wash the disciples’ feet, and to wipe them with the towel he was wrapped in.

6.verse: He came to Simon Peter. ‘Master,’ said Peter, ‘what’s this? You, washing my feet?’

7.verse: ‘You don’t understand yet what I’m doing,’ replied Jesus, ‘but you’ll know afterwards.’

8.verse: ‘I’m not going to have you washing my feet!’ said Peter. ‘Never!’ ‘If I don’t wash you,’ replied Jesus, ‘you don’t belong to me.’

9.verse: ‘All right then, Master,’ said Simon Peter, ‘but not only my feet – wash my hands and my head as well!’

10.verse: ‘Someone who has washed’, said Jesus to him, ‘doesn’t need to wash again, except for their feet. They are clean all over. And you are clean – but not all of you.’

11.verse: Jesus knew, you see, who was going to betray him. That’s why he said, ‘You are not all clean.’

12.verse: Like Master, Like Servant - So when he had washed their feet, he put on his clothes and sat down again. ‘Do you know what I’ve done to you?’ he asked.

13.verse: ‘You call me “teacher”, and “master”, and you’re right. That’s what I am.

14.verse: Well, then: if I, as your master and teacher, washed your feet just now, you should wash each other’s feet.

15.verse: I’ve given you a pattern, so that you can do things in the same way that I did to you.

16.verse: ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ he continued. ‘The slave isn’t greater than the master. People who are sent are not greater than the person who sends them.

17.verse: If you know these things, God’s blessing on you if you do them.

18.verse: ‘I’m not talking about all of you,’ he went on. ‘I know the ones I have chosen. What the Bible says has to come true: “The person who ate my bread lifted up his heel against me.”

19.verse: I’m telling you this now, before it happens, so that when it does happen you may believe that I am who I am.

20.verse: I’m telling you the solemn truth: anyone who welcomes someone I send, welcomes me, and anyone who welcomes me, welcomes the one who sent me.’

21.verse: Judas Goes Out - After saying this, Jesus was troubled in spirit. He told them why. ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ he said. ‘One of you will betray me.’

22.verse: The disciples looked at each other in shock, wondering who he could be talking about.

23.verse: One of the disciples, the one Jesus specially loved, was reclining at table close beside him.

24.verse: Simon Peter motioned to him to ask who it was he was talking about.

25.verse: So, leaning back against Jesus’ chest, he asked him, ‘Who is it, Master?’

26.verse: ‘It’s the one I’m going to give this piece of bread to’, said Jesus, ‘when I’ve dipped it in the dish.’ So he dipped the piece of bread, and gave it to Judas, son of Simon Iscariot.

27.verse: After the bread, the satan entered into him. ‘Do it quickly, won’t you?’ said Jesus to him.

28.verse: None of the others at the table knew what he meant.

29.verse: Because Judas kept the common purse, some were thinking that he meant, ‘Buy what we need for the festival’, or that he was to give something to the poor.

30.verse: So when Judas had taken the bread, he went out at once. It was night.

31.verse: Love One Another - When Judas had gone out, Jesus began to speak. ‘Now the son of man is glorified!’ he said. ‘Now God is glorified in him!

32.verse: And if God is glorified in him, God will glorify him in himself, and glorify him at once.

33.verse: Children, I’m only with you a little longer. You will look for me, and, as I said to the Judaeans that where I was going they couldn’t come, so I’m saying the same to you now.

34.verse: ‘I’m giving you a new commandment, and it’s this: love one another! Just as I have loved you, so you must love one another.

35.verse: This is how everybody will know that you are my disciples, if you have love for each other.’

36.verse: Simon Peter spoke up. ‘Master,’ he said, ‘where are you going?’ ‘Where I’m going’, replied Jesus, ‘you can’t follow me just now. You will follow later, though.’

37.verse: ‘Master,’ Peter replied, ‘why can’t I follow you now? I will lay down my life for you!’

38.verse: ‘Will you really lay down your life for me?’ smiled Jesus. ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth: by the time the cock crows you will have disowned me three times.’

1.verse: The Way, the Truth, the Life - ‘Don’t let your hearts be troubled,’ Jesus continued. ‘Trust God – and trust me, too!

2.verse: There is plenty of room to live in my father’s house. If that wasn’t the case, I’d have told you, wouldn’t I? I’m going to get a place ready for you!

3.verse: And if I do go and get a place ready for you, I will come back and take you to be with me, so that you can be there, where I am.

4.verse: And as to where I’m going – you know the way!’

5.verse: ‘Actually, Master,’ said Thomas to him, ‘we don’t know where you’re going, so how can we know the way?’

6.verse: ‘I am the way,’ replied Jesus, ‘and the truth and the life! Nobody comes to the father except through me.

7.verse: If you had known me, you would have known my father. From now on you do know him! You have seen him.’

8.verse: ‘Just show us the father, then, Master,’ said Philip to Jesus, ‘and that’ll be good enough for us!’

9.verse: ‘Have I been with you for such a long time, Philip,’ replied Jesus, ‘and still you don’t know me? Anyone who has seen me has seen the father! How can you say, “Show us the father”?

10.verse: Don’t you believe that I am in the father, and the father is in me? The words I’m speaking to you, I’m not speaking on my own initiative. It’s the father, who lives within me, who is doing his own works.

11.verse: You must trust me that I am in the father and the father is in me. If not, then trust because of all the things you’ve seen done.’

12.verse: Another Helper - ‘I’m telling you the solemn truth,’ Jesus continued. ‘Anyone who trusts in me will also do the works that I’m doing. In fact, they will do greater works than these, because I’m going to the father!

13.verse: And whatever you ask in my name, I will do it, so that the father may be glorified in the son.

14.verse: If you ask anything in my name, I will do it.

15.verse: ‘If you love me,’ he went on, ‘you will keep my commands.

16.verse: And I will ask the father, and he will give you another helper, to be with you for ever.

17.verse: This other helper is the spirit of truth. The world can’t receive him, because it doesn’t see him or know him. But you know him, because he lives with you, and will be in you.

18.verse: ‘I’m not going to leave you bereft. I am coming to you.

19.verse: Not long from now, the world won’t see me any more; but you will see me. Because I live, you will live too.

20.verse: On that day you will know that I am in my father, and you in me, and I in you.

21.verse: ‘Anyone who has my commandments and keeps them – that’s the person who loves me. Anyone who loves me will be loved by my father, and I will love them and show myself to them.’
